issue.title: ci: also test on macOS M1

labels.name: ci
labels.description: automation for build, test, and release

repository.name: neovim
repository.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability

issue.body:
GH Actions run macos-14 on M1 now, giving us our first ARM build.

Test both arches for now; we can eventually drop Intel in favor of ARM to reduce the test load (and will have to, once Apple drops support for Intel completely). M1 runners seem about twice as fast, at least at this moment:

* macos-12:
  - Build 48s
  - functionaltest 7m 7s

* macos-14:
  - Build 24s
  - functionaltest 5m 5s

unittest failure is relevant and due to arch difference, see #26145 

(oldttest failure is also relevant and due to building without `libintl`: one is straight locale failure (though behind `has('gettext')` guard?), the other is in `Wildmode_test()` and unclear)

**Question:** Do we want to move the build/release tests to M1 (once we get the unittest fixed)?

@dundargoc

issue.title: tests: improve test conventions (SUT, helpers.lua)

labels.name: refactor
labels.description: changes that are not features or bugfixes

milestone.title: backlog
milestone.description: Low priority items. We plan to work on this but don't have a target date.

repository.name: neovim
repository.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability

issue.body:
# Problem

Writing test code requires some "tribal knowledge" that requires the test author to understand which "helper" functions are dispatched to the `nvim` _test session_ (the "[SUT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_under_test)") and which functions are handled in the context of the _test runner_.

Contributors must constantly be aware of the difference. Reading and writing tests can be confusing because of this, especially to non-experienced contributors.

# Expected behavior

Make the distinction clear by either extracting SUT functions to `test/sut.lua` or grouping them in a ~~sut~~ `nvim` container.

- [x] Rename `helpers.lua` to `testutil.lua` and change the import convention to (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/28145):
   ```
   local t = require('testutil')
   ...
   t.foo()
   t.bar()
   ```
    - Thus there is no need anymore to do this:
      ```
      local helpers = require('testutil')
      local foo = helpers.foo
      local bar = helpers.bar
      ```
    - Test code can simply use `t.xx()` everywhere to call non-SUT test util functions.
- [x] #28472
   ```lua
   nvim.api.nvim_get_commands()  -- instead of helpers.api.nvim_get_commands
   nvim.fn.foo()  -- instead of helpers.fn.foo()
   ```
    - See "Implementation" below.

# Implementation

Almost everything in `test/functional/testutil.lua` involves a "session". So in practice this would mean:

1. Lift any "pure" functionality (functions that don't require the nvim "test session") from `test/functional/testutil.lua` into `test/testutil.lua`.
    - `test/functional/testutil.lua` calls the `nvim` "test session" via RPC.
1. `test/testutil.lua` is no longer "merged" into `test/functional/testutil.lua`.
    - I.e. delete this line: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/fd085d90820149caecf213b299f19e46305043ee/test/functional/testutil.lua#L19
1. Rename `test/functional/testutil.lua` to (e.g.) `…/nvimsession.lua`
1. All test imports now look like:
   ```lua
   -- Test runner functions/utils.
   local t = require('test.testutil')()
   -- Nvim RPC session.
   local nvim = require('test.functional.nvimsession')()
   ```
    - What should the test session be named?
        - ~~nvim? session? sut?~~ We decided on `n`.

# Future

Some questions to consider for the future (out of scope for this issue):

- Should `nvim` be a mirror of the nvim "test session" Lua stdlib? I.e. all `nvim.xx()` calls just dispatch to the Nvim "test session" `vim.xx()` ?
- Currently, we have a global "session": https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/f190f758ac58d9cc955368e047b070e0a2261033/test/functional/testutil.lua#L107-L113
    - This makes it less obvious what's going on in the tests.
    - It is weird that "screen" is used as an object in test code while "session" is not. Especially since the "screen" object is strictly tied to a session anyway. You cannot have multiple screens per session.
    - Solution: we could treat the Nvim session same as "screen", so tests would look like:
      ```
      local nvim = require('…/nvimsession.lua')
      local n = nvim.clear()
      n:command(':new foo')
      t.eq(2, n:eval('1+1'))
      ```

# Related

- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26994
- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27024

body:
This is a LuaJIT parsing issue https://github.com/LuaJIT/LuaJIT/issues/951, below is a very hacky work around. LuaJIT FFI doesn't support bitfields or the C++11 `enum : type` extension.

After that, all the unittests are passing.

The best fix would be to support it properly in LuaJIT, I'm not sure of the best way to work around it in neovim.

```
diff --git a/test/unit/testutil.lua b/test/unit/testutil.lua                                                                                                                          
index c90859581..de8bb2f31 100644                                                                                                                                                     
--- a/test/unit/testutil.lua                                                                                                                                                          
+++ b/test/unit/testutil.lua                                                                                                                                                          
@@ -265,6 +265,14 @@ local function _cimportstr(preprocess_cache, path)                                                                                                               
   if body == '' then                                                                                                                                                                 
     return lib                                                                                                                                                                       
   end                                                                                                                                                                                
+  body = body:gsub('typedef enum : uint32_t', 'typedef enum')                                                                                                                        
+  body = body:gsub('typedef enum : uint64_t', 'typedef enum')                                                                                                                        
+  body = body:gsub('typedef enum : uint16_t', 'typedef enum')                                                                                                                        
+  body = body:gsub('mach_vm_range_flags_t flags: 48; mach_vm_range_tag_t range_tag : 8; uint8_t vm_tag : 8; struct mach_vm_range range;', 'mach_vm_range_flags_t flags; mach_vm_range
_tag_t range_tag; uint8_t vm_tag; struct mach_vm_range range;') 
```
Cool. Want to raise a PR to add that patch as a temporary workaround?

I could, it felt too horrible to use as a hack even, was hoping someone might have some better ideas. A PR could work as a place to try figure out alternatives though.

I also don't know how 'temporary' it would be, not sure if LuaJIT is going to implement the changes needed.

A nasty, but small, hack is much better than unittests not working IMO. This also affects all macos builds going forward since x86 is being phased out.

@dundargoc what do you think of the workaround?

> I also don't know how 'temporary' it would be, not sure if LuaJIT is going to implement the changes needed.

No I wouldn't hold your breath. However since this affects system headers on a major platform, an exception might be made.

Another alternative I tried was to define `_MACH_VM_TYPES_H_` but I think that lead to just a different error later since another header needed one of the types.

It's kinda crazy this low-level of a header is pulled in.
Where is it being pulled in? Can we avoid it if it isn't strictly needed?

Yes, PR welcome. This is not any hackier than what we're already doing in unittest, which is straight up ignoring anything we can't parse: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/test/unit/testutil.lua#L130-L156

As an example, adding `or string.find(line, 'typedef enum : uint32_t')` instead of `body = body:gsub('typedef enum : uint32_t', 'typedef enum')` works as well. This didn't work for uint64_t for some reason, but my point is that skipping unparsable sections isn't any less hacky than changing the code to be parseable.

Please make a PR :)

@lewis6991 I think through `stdbool.h` but that's just a guess, would be hard to figure out I think. (I'm running linux+arm64 locally, but trying to fix the macOS issues so we have arm64 coverage)

@dundargoc thanks, I didn't see that bit of code, feel a bit better with my hack now!

issue.title: ci: enable unittests on macos-14

labels.name: ci
labels.description: automation for build, test, and release

repository.name: neovim
repository.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability

issue.body:
Fix the LuaJIT issues by filtering out lines that are too complex.

Then enable CI for macOS 14 on M1! 

This closes #26145.
